0.points:
What Philosophy Is

  • Philosophy as all of rational inquiry except for science
  • Metaphysics, epistemology, and ethics as the three big topic areas of philosophy
  • Metaphysics as concerned with the nature of reality
  • Epistemology as concerned with the nature of knowledge and justified belief
  • Ethics as concerned with what we ought to do, how we ought to live, and how we ought to organize our communities
0.script: What is philosophy? Many answers have been offered to this question, but my favorite answer is that philosophy is all of rational inquiry except for science.

1.points:
Metaphysics

  • Metaphysical issues concerned with the nature of reality
  • Various metaphysical questions and historical attempts to establish systematic metaphysical world views
  • Return of metaphysics to vitality and its aims in contemporary analytic metaphysics
1.script: Philosophy explores questions about the nature of reality (metaphysics), the nature of knowledge and justified belief (epistemology), and how we ought to live and organize our communities (ethics).

2.points:
Epistemology

  • Epistemology concerned with the nature of knowledge and justified belief
  • Questions about skepticism and knowledge in different areas
  • Importance of rational justification and relevance of beliefs
2.script: While philosophy does not always provide definitive answers, it enables us to explore new possibilities and opens our minds to different perspectives.

3.points:
Ethics

  • Ethics concerned with what we ought to do, how we ought to live, and how we ought to organize our communities
  • Contrast with religously inspired views about morality
  • Importance of rational inquiry into moral questions
  • Challenges in establishing definitive answers in ethics
3.script: The value of philosophy lies in its ability to challenge our assumptions, liberate us from narrow-minded thinking, and encourage critical inquiry.

4.points:
The Value of Philosophy

  • Value of philosophy in loosening the grip of uncritically held opinions
  • Importance of uncertainty in philosophy and the liberation it brings
  • Choice between feeling of safety and liberty of open inquiry
  • Possibility of progress and right answers in philosophy
